transcript:
Therapist: You mentioned that your depression has been affecting your sleep and your interest in activities you used to enjoy. Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have been impacting your daily life and relationships?

Patient: Well, I've been having a hard time focusing at work, which is really unlike me. I used to be able to dive into projects and stay focused for hours, but now I find my mind wandering, and I'm making more mistakes than usual. It's frustrating because I know I'm capable of doing better, but I just can't seem to get out of this fog.

Therapist: It sounds like your depression is really taking a toll on your work performance, which is understandably frustrating for you. How have your symptoms been affecting your relationship with your partner, Lian?

Patient: Lian has been really supportive, but I feel like I'm not being a good partner to them. I'm often too tired or unmotivated to do things together, and I know it's putting a strain on our relationship. I want to be there for Lian, but it's hard when I'm feeling so low myself.

Therapist: It's common for depression to affect relationships, and it's good that you have a supportive partner like Lian. As we work together in therapy, we'll explore ways to help you manage your symptoms and improve your communication with Lian. Speaking of your personal history, you mentioned that you grew up in a military family and moved around a lot. How do you think this experience has influenced your life and your current struggles with depression?

Patient: Growing up, I always felt like an outsider because we moved so often. I had a hard time making friends and felt like I didn't really belong anywhere. I think that experience made me really self-reliant, but it also left me with a sense of loneliness and disconnection. I sometimes wonder if that feeling of not belonging is contributing to my depression now.

Therapist: That's a really insightful observation, Mei. Childhood experiences can definitely shape the way we see ourselves and the world around us. The sense of disconnection and loneliness you experienced growing up could be playing a role in your current struggles. As we continue with therapy, we'll explore these connections further and work on developing a stronger sense of belonging and connection in your life. How do you feel about what we've discussed so far today?

Patient: It's been really helpful to talk about these things and start making connections between my past experiences and my current struggles. I feel like I'm starting to understand myself better, and I'm hopeful that therapy can help me find ways to cope with my depression and build a more fulfilling life.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that you're finding our discussion helpful, Mei. It's a great sign that you're already making connections and gaining insight into your experiences. As we continue with the assessment process, we'll dive deeper into these areas and start setting goals for your treatment. In our next session, we'll begin to explore some CBT concepts and techniques that can help you manage your depression and work towards the life you want to live. How does that sound to you?

Patient: That sounds really good. I'm looking forward to learning more about CBT and starting to make some positive changes in my life. Thank you for listening and helping me start this process.

Therapist: You're welcome, Mei. It's my pleasure to support you on this journey. Remember, therapy is a collaborative process, and your input and engagement are crucial to its success. If you ever have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to bring them up. We're in this together, and I'm here to help you every step of the way.
